data.title: ILR Thursday Courses | Continuing Education
data.text:
Alzheimer’s Association Educational Series

April 4 – Healthy Living for Your Brain and Body – The health of the brain and body are connected. Diet and nutrition, exercise, cognitive activity, and social engagement are essential tools in every plan for healthy aging.

April 11 – 10 Warning Signs of Alzheimer’s – Alzheimer’s and other dementias can change memory, thinking and behavior. Once you have learned the 10 common warning signs, you’ll understand what to watch for in yourself and others.

April 18 – Understanding Alzheimer’s and Dementia – Alzheimer’s is not part of normal aging. Learn about the impact of Alzheimer’s, the difference between Alzheimer’s and dementia, Alzheimer’s disease stages and risk factors, and current research and treatments.

April 25 – Effective Communication Strategies – Caregivers must understand how to decode verbal and behavioral communication by someone with Alzheimer’s and other dementias in order to maintain meaningful connection, despite how far the disease has progressed.

May 2 – Understanding and Responding to Dementia Related Behaviors – Behavioral aspects of dementia can be addressed using a four-step model. We will learn the details of the model and then apply it to some of the most common behaviors associated with the disease.

Coordinator: Kelsey Nihiser joined the Alzheimer’s Association, Greater Cincinnati Chapter, in February 2023 after working in local nonprofits for the arts, art education, community education, and mental health education. Her work in creative communities and her family history with dementia fostered her passion for supporting people and connecting them to resources.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 9:00–10:15 am

Format: In person

Location: West Chester, Chesterwood Village, Monarch Theatre

Do You Need a Financial Adviser?

We will discuss everything you need to know about financial advisors, such as qualifications and education, professionalism, the types of firms that hire advisors, and the cost of hiring an adviser. The goal of this course is to address the value advisers can provide and whether there are alternatives to hiring one. We will follow up on information from last semester’s “Basic Financial Investing” course, although attendance of the previous course is not required.

Instructor: Walter Frank retired in 2008 after a 38-year-long career as the Vice President, Senior Investment Advisor at Merrill Lynch. Walter is certified by Columbia University Academy of Certified Portfolio Managers.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 9:00–10:15 am

Format: Virtual

Location: Online

Backyard Photography

Join like-minded nature photography enthusiasts as we meet at a different local park each week to enjoy the landscape through the lens of a camera. We will visit Pine Hill Lakes Park, Bull’s Run Nature Sanctuary and Arboretum, Rentschler Forest, Heritage Village at Sharon Woods, and Kingswood Park or Miller Ecological Park. A basic knowledge of photography and a willingness to share your photos online with the group is desirable. This class requires some walking on trails and uneven ground.

Instructors: Marianne Schulz is an avid amateur photographer interested in nature and landscape photography in the Cincinnati and Dayton areas. Nancy Woody is a retired art teacher for Lakota School District and has a strong interest in photography.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 9:30–11:15 am

Format: In person

Location: See description above; the first class will meet at Pine Hill Lakes Park in the parking lot on the left after entering the park (near the playground) NOTE: Heritage Village at Sharon Woods Park has a $10 admission fee; Sharon Woods Park has a $5 admission fee for Hamilton County residents and an $8 admission fee for non-county residents. Class cancellation due to weather will result in a makeup week added (maximum of two).

Explorations in Meditation

Embark on a transformative journey of self-discovery with this meditation course rooted in the rich traditions of yoga. This immersive program invites participants to explore a diverse array of meditation techniques rooted in yogic wisdom. From mindfulness and breath awareness to mantra meditation and guided visualization, the course provides a holistic exploration of practices aimed at cultivating inner peace, mental clarity, and spiritual growth. Wear comfortable, breathable clothing such as yoga pants, leggings, or loose-fitting pants to allow for ease of movement. We will be seated on the floor on a yoga mat and meditation cushion (both provided, but feel free to bring your own if you prefer).

Instructor: Jessica Lohrey is an Oxford native, a Miami grad, and owner of Oxford Community Yoga.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 10:45–11:45 am

Format: In person

Location: Oxford Community Yoga

Travel with Friends: Adriatic Sea and the Dalmatian Coast

“Travel with Friends” is a continuation of adventures shared in previous ILR classes by MaryEllen and Bill Haynes. This series will take you on our small boat adventure in 2022 to the Dalmatian Coast along the Adriatic Sea, visiting Greece, Albania, Montenegro, and Croatia. We will also present on our most recent trip to Ireland in September, 2023, where we learned about Irish history, especially the turbulent period called “The Troubles,” which continued until 1998. You will experience the beauty of the green isle; its ancient history; its warm, friendly citizens; and the complicated political turmoil that is still simmering under the surface as Irish citizens confront division in their country.

Instructor: MaryEllen Haynes has been an avid world traveler since retirement.

4 Thursdays: April 4–25; 10:45 am–noon

Format: In person

Location: West Chester, VOALC, Auditorium

A Salute to Veterans: Hear Their Stories

Join fellow veterans to share your most interesting or entertaining stories about your time in the service of our country. Each week we will have a topic (e.g., “basic training” or “overseas adventures”) with a selected member of the group starting the discussion. Other members will then be invited to share their stories on the topic. The funnier the better, but please, no X-rated tales! This is a great way for vets to enjoy the camaraderie of others who have served. All are welcome, irrespective of military service or not.

Instructors: Paul Allen is a retired U.S. Navy officer who served 24 years and has lots of sea stories, some of which are true. Jerry Riesenberg is a U.S. Air Force Veteran who served in Vietnam. He is a mainstay of the ILR Program.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 10:45 am–noon

Format: In person

Location: Oxford, Boyd Hall, Room 117

Thursday Midday Lecture Series

This spring brings us another exciting lineup of fascinating topics brought to us by experienced speakers.

April 4 – What Happened to the Cincinnati Enquirer? – John Kiesewetter worked for 40 years at the Cincinnati Enquirer during the peak of its circulation and staff size.

April 11 – Joe Nuxhall: The Old Lefthander and Me – John Kiesewetter interviewed Nuxhall many times, often recording the conversations, which became the basis for John’s new book.

April 18 – FDR’s Funeral Train – Deb Price will tell the tale of how FDR was returned to Hyde Park, N.Y, from Warm Springs, Georgia, through the herculean efforts of engineers, family, and even a spy.

April 25 – Pharmocracy: How Big Pharma Took Over the World – Debbi Silverman will discuss the issues in our broken healthcare system and the history of how it came to be that way.

May 2 – Working Dogs – Deb Price knows how dogs make human jobs easier. From the beagles who guard our airports from illegal materials to dogs that sniff out cancerous tumors, dogs truly are man’s best friend.

Coordinator: Jane Gegner is a longtime volunteer on the ILR curriculum committee. She is dedicated to bringing quality speakers and interesting new topics to lifelong learners.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 12:30–1:45 pm

Format: In person

Location: West Chester, Chesterwood Village, Monarch Theatre

The Role of Age in Film

“The Role of Age in Film” is an engaging 5-week course that delves into the cinematic representation of older adults and the aging process. Through a curated selection of films, this course explores the multifaceted dimensions of later life, challenging stereotypes, and encouraging critical thinking about aging in society. Students will have the opportunity to watch, analyze, and discuss a diverse range of films that portray aging in various ways, from heartwarming and comedic to thought-provoking

and poignant.

Instructor: Samuel Van Vleet is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Sociology and Gerontology at Miami University. Samuel has a background in film and creative writing, which includes creating his own video production company geared towards highlighting older adult voices. Samuel writes, directs, and edits his own short films and documentaries.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 12:30–1:45 pm

Format: In person

Location: Oxford, Boyd Hall, Room 217

Killer Bugs in Hospitals

We will discuss the five most common hospital-acquired (nosocomial) infections and their impact on individuals and the healthcare system. These infections include: catheter-associated urinary tract infections, central line (IV) associated bloodstream infection, surgical site and/or wound infection (MRSA, etc.), Clostridium difficile (c-diff), and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Instructor: John Stevenson, Professor Emeritus of Microbiology, retired from Miami in 2015 after 41 years of teaching and research focused on immunology and infectious diseases.

6 Thursdays: April 4–May 9; 12:30–1:45 pm

Format: Virtual

Location: Online

Art Quilting for Everyone

This hands-on whimsical art quilting class is for everyone—no experience needed. Let quilt artist Linda Kramer guide you through this playful art quilting experience, using an ordinary log cabin block pattern to create an extraordinary mini art quilt. You do not need any quilting, art, or design experience. All you need is a willingness to try something new, an open mind for a new way of thinking about quilting, and a sewing machine that you know how to use. Carts will be provided to assist with moving your sewing machine and supplies. This is a hands-on, 90-minute class with an extra optional hour after class to work on your quilt block with individual attention from the instructor.

Supplies: A supply list will be emailed upon registration.

Instructor: Linda Kramer is an alumna of Miami University and an accomplished artist, quilter, and teacher.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 9; 12:30–2:00 pm

Format: In person

Location: Hamilton, Berkeley Square, Haith Dining Room

NOTE: No class 4/18

Exploring the Wonders of Classical Music

You don’t have to know anything about classical music to enjoy it. We will listen for many enduring characteristics of music, such as theme and variations, melody, harmony and composers’ use of humor. Come discover the joys of listening to classical music with new understanding.

Instructor: Musician Ruthanna Jeter, who studied at the Jacobs School of Music at Indiana University and is a long-time teacher of different disciplines of music, wants to engage with you in some wonderful ways to listen to classical music.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 2:15–3:30 pm

Format: In person

Location: Monroe, Ohio Living Mt. Pleasant, Chapel

Let’s Read and Discuss Elie Wiesel’s Night

Night is a 1960’s memoir by Elie Wiesel based on his Holocaust experiences with his father in the Nazi German concentration camps at Auschwitz and Buchenwald during 1944-45, toward the end of World War II in Europe. This short work (9 chapters) was originally published in 1965. We will read two chapters a week. Please have chapters one and two read for the first session of class.

Class Text: Elie Wiesel, Night, Bantam Books, 1982, (Mass Paperback Edition) ISBN 9780553272536

Instructor: Lisa Burnett is a retired high school English teacher who enjoys reading and reviewing classic literature.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 2:15–3:15 pm

Format: Virtual

Location: Online

Behind the Music: A History of the Recording Industry from a Marketing Perspective

Technological advancements have changed how music is created, produced, distributed, promoted, and sold. These changes in turn often carried significant socio-cultural impacts. Following a brief summary of technological innovations prior to the 20th century (e.g., the printing press), we will focus on trends in the music business over the past 100 years. Examples of innovations for discussion include the phonograph, radio, multi-track recording, electric guitar, jukebox, synthesizers, digitization and CDs, MTV, MP3s, online streaming, and social media. We will listen to, or view, recordings from each decade that illustrate the presented concepts.

Instructor: Kevin Stephens was a full-time instructor in the Miami University marketing department for five years before retiring in 2020. Prior to that he spent several decades in marketing communications and senior executive positions in the private sector. As a lifelong musician, Stephens has abundant interest in and enthusiasm for the course subject matter.

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 2:15–3:30 pm

Format: In person

Location: Oxford, Boyd Hall, Room 228

Films Featuring Hawks, Newman, Redford, Connery, and Sutherland

Based upon recommendations from a previous class, we will feature movies from four actors (Sean Connery, Donald Sutherland, Paul Newman, and Robert Redford) and one director (Howard Hawks). In each three-hour class session, we will watch an entire movie and then have a discussion. Films include:

April 4 – Bringing Up Baby (dir. Howard Hawks, 1938) 1h 42m: A screwball comedy starring Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn.

April 11 – The First Great Train Robbery (dir. Michael Crichton, 1978) 1h 50m: Heist film based upon a real incident, with Sean Connery and Donald Sutherland.

April 18 – The Sting (dir. George Roy Hill, 1973) 2h 9m: Newman and Redford mastermind a con game, featuring Scott Joplin music.

April 25 – Three Days of the Condor (dir. Sydney Pollack, 1975) 1h 58m: CIA agent Redford is on the run when his team is killed.

May 2 – M*A*S*H (dir. Robert Altman, 1970) 1h 56m: Hijinks in a MASH medical unit in Korea with Sutherland and Elliott Gould.

Instructor: Doug Iden is an avid theatergoer and movie buff with an extensive collection of films and original Broadway musical scores. Doug is also a critic for the League of Cincinnati Theatres (LCT).

5 Thursdays: April 4–May 2; 2:15–5:15 pm

Format: In person

Location: West Chester, Chesterwood Village, Monarch Theatre

The Imminent Solar Eclipse

On April 8, a total solar eclipse, a rare and spectacular event, will cross North America, passing over Mexico, the United States, and Canada. Only 21 total solar eclipses have crossed the lower 48 states in the entire existence of the United States, and those within a 124-mile-wide band in the state of Ohio will experience a front row seat. Why is this a big deal? Because the last total solar eclipse visible in Ohio was in 1806, and the next one won’t come our way until the year 2099, so you’ll want to learn how best to experience this special astronomical event.

Instructors: Jerry Riesenberg has been an amateur astronomer for more than 45 years. He has built his own telescopes and has traveled to five national observatories and has observed four solar eclipses. Stephen Alexander is Associate Professor, Miami University Department of Physics, and also teaches astronomy.

1 Thursday: April 4; 4:00–5:15 pm

Format: Hybrid

Location: Online or Richard and Carole Cocks Art Museum

Invitation to the Dance: The Role of Ballet in Opera

Ballet and dance have been associated with opera from its very beginnings in Florence and Venice until today. We will share ballet scenes and arias from operas by Monteverdi, Gluck, Lully, Rameau, Bizet and Borodin: Orfeo, Orfeo ed Euridice, Persée, Les Indes galantes, Carmen, Prince Igor, and Mark Morris’s Dido and Aeneas.

Instructors: Anne Morris-Hooke is a retired Miami microbiology professor with a lifelong passion for opera. Andrea Ridilla, Professor of Music at Miami, teaches oboe and opera appreciation.

5 Thursdays: April 11–May 9; 4:00–5:15 pm

Format: Virtual

Location: Online

NOTE: Late start/end date

A Greenhorn Goy Goes to Israel

Learn and laugh as you follow the account of a young, naïve Midwesterner recounting her experiences while living on an Israeli Kibbutz and traveling around the country. This class delves into daily life, customs, and the survival tactics necessary to exist in a country constantly under threat from both internal and external enemies.

Instructor: Rebecca Evans lived on a kibbutz in Israel for four months shortly after the death of Anwar Sadat. She traveled the country to experience its landscape, archaeology and historical sites.
